data.title: true crime
data.meta_description: TRUE CRIME meaning: 1. books and films about real crimes that involved real people:  2. books and movies about real…. Learn more.

noun [ U ]

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˌtruː ˈkraɪm/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˌtruː ˈkraɪm/

More examplesFewer examples

I've read a lot of true crime.

Until Proven Innocent is a compelling true crime book.

The story is the subject of a novel by best-selling true crime writer Ann Rule.

(Definition of true crime from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of true crime

true crime

Lots of true crime is focused on descriptions and reenactments, she says.

The true crime doc is a burgeoning genre.

As with all things true crime, there's a great deal of ambiguity here.

But too often in the true crime genre there is a tendency to lose the forest for the trees.

I really have no "favorite" true crime writer.

But true crime can get more true and more shaky at the same time.

There's nothing wrong with that; true crime shows and even books do it routinely.

The new school of true crime stories covers everything from little-known crimes, barely covered by the local press, to trials that received wall-to-wall media coverage.

That virtual conversation, in turn, prompts people to tune into true crime shows because they are afraid of missing out on the newest cultural phenomenon.

Perhaps he's the one with the true crime-fighting gift!

In this bubbling beaker of a book, she mixes up a heady potion of forensic toxicology, history and true crime.

A lot of times the true crime stories that are looking at cultural phenomenons fall into a different camp than documentaries that are almost investigatory in nature.

For those who view true crime as a sort of impersonal form of "entertainment," like a horror movie, this could explain the appeal of murderabilia, at least for some collectors.

The problem is that those who are watching don't realize how they have moved from being passive viewers in a true crime story to becoming participants.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
